stages.description: A large kidney-shaped seed with a smooth white coat. Satisfyingly chunky — even children can handle and plant them.
The hypocotyl arch pushes through the soil, hauling the fat cotyledons into daylight. Provider germinates in cooler soil than most beans dare.
Thick pale cotyledons unfold like two fleshy wings. The first true leaves are simple and heart-shaped — the trifoliates come next.
Rapid bushy growth. Trifoliate leaves crowd together on short petioles, forming a dense rounded canopy. Root nodules are already fixing atmospheric nitrogen.
Small white papilionaceous flowers emerge at leaf axils, each a perfect miniature of the sweet pea. Self-pollinating — every flower can become a pod.
Slender round pods elongate rapidly beneath the foliage, hanging in clusters of two or three. Pick them young and tender — wait too long and they turn fibrous.
Leaves yellow and drop. Remaining pods dry to papery shells rattling with next year's seed. The root nodules leave a gift of nitrogen in the soil.

companions.lore: The original Three Sisters — beans fix atmospheric nitrogen into the soil, feeding the hungry corn. In return, tall corn stalks can shelter low bean bushes from wind.
The third Sister. Squash sprawls beneath bean bushes, its broad leaves shading the soil to retain moisture and suppress weeds for both crops.
Bean root nodules release nitrogen that feeds the carrot's taproot. Carrots loosen deep soil that beans' shallow roots can't reach.

antagonists.lore: Fennel's root exudates are toxic to most legumes, stunting bean growth and interfering with nitrogen fixation.
Alliums release sulfurous compounds that inhibit Rhizobium bacteria in bean root nodules, crippling their ability to fix nitrogen.

stages.description: Small reddish-brown pustules erupt on leaf undersides — each one a volcano of rust spores. Upper leaf surface shows faint yellow halos.
Pustules multiply across the foliage. Leaves yellow and drop prematurely, thinning the canopy. Pod production slows as the plant loses photosynthetic capacity.
Severe defoliation. The plant is a skeleton of bare stems with a few yellow leaves clinging on. Any remaining pods are stunted.
Lower leaves yellow for no obvious reason. Growth slows. Underground, Pythium or Rhizoctonia fungi are consuming the roots.
Plant wilts in midday heat even though soil is moist. Roots are brown and mushy — they can no longer absorb water. The nitrogen-fixing nodules are destroyed.
Complete collapse. Pull the plant and the roots will be dark, slimy, and foul-smelling. Waterlogged soil was the death sentence.
Small dark sunken lesions appear on pods and stems, often along the veins. Spread by rain splash from infected soil.
Lesions enlarge with salmon-pink spore masses visible in wet weather. Pod quality is ruined — dark streaks penetrate to the seeds inside.

lore.description: A dependable bush bean bred for cold tolerance and early production — 'Provider' earned its name by providing when other varieties fail.
lore.origin: United States, developed by the USDA in the 1960s for reliable performance in cool, wet spring conditions
lore.fun_fact: Provider beans can germinate in soil as cool as 15°C, while most beans refuse to sprout below 18°C — making them the go-to variety for impatient spring planters.
